nodes.text: The organization form (firm versus market and the internal structure of firms) is determined by informational and metering costs of allocating rewards to inputs in team production
Metering problem: efficient organization requires measuring input productivity and apportioning rewards, and metering is costly when outputs or contributions are hard to observe
Team production is production where multiple inputs jointly produce output that is not separable into additive individual outputs, making individual marginal products hard to observe
When metering is costly in team production, individual input owners have incentives to shirk because private detection costs are lower than social costs, lowering realized effort

Specializing a monitor who holds the residual claim (residual claimant) reduces shirking by aligning the monitor's incentives with team output and enables centralized contract revision and membership control

The classical firm is a contractual structure defined by: joint input production, multiple input owners, a single common party to all input contracts who holds residual rights and unilateral rights to revise membership and sell those rights
Residual-claimant monitoring substitutes for costly market metering when the monitor can observe input behavior and unilaterally adjust contracts to discipline shirking
Assumption: more than pecuniary rewards enter utility functions so that nonpecuniary leisure and amenities matter and make shirking relevant to organization choice

Prediction about profit sharing: profit sharing is more viable for small teams or professional/artistic production because self-policing and reciprocal monitoring reduce shirking costs when team size is small

Prediction about corporations: for large, diffused ownership the firm evolves mechanisms (limited liability, transferability of shares, delegation to managers) to concentrate decision authority and enable market replacement of management

Prediction about other organizational forms: partnerships, unions, mutuals, nonprofits and socialist firms arise when monitoring costs, political constraints, or the nature of inputs favor profit sharing, member control, or alternative policing devices

Claim about asset ownership: inputs whose user costs or depreciation are easier to detect when the owner is present (portable tools, durable capital) tend to be owner-owned rather than rented; this affects incidence of tenancy, sharecropping, and hiring

The firm as information market: firms function as specialized private markets that collect, collate, and sell information about heterogeneous inputs, enabling superior internal recombinations and intrafirm competition among inputs

Conclusion: the contractual firm (central monitor with residual rights) emerges because it economizes on costly metering in team production and yields testable implications across firm types, ownership of inputs, and organizational practices

Limitation: other sources of high policing or informational costs (e.g., quality attributes, hard-to-observe contingent features) may induce contractual arrangements different from the firm defined here and were not analyzed in depth
